utterances: So I think symbolically and in a very real way that this is the end of the end.
And the fact that we're talking about a surge, or our president is talking about the surge, and his main ally is talking about withdrawal is significant.
Before you jump in.
John, at one point, you said you are willing to go over and fight.
So I'm…
Yeah.
It is still a fantasy, though, right?
I mean, fabulous outfits.
You are working in fashion.

You know, it's a little bit ""Devil Wears Prada,"" little bit ""Sex And The City."" How do you balance that idea of wanting to be, like, real and authentic and strip away all the artifice and at the same time live in that universe?
Well, this is Katie.

I think one of the important things to take away from the show is kind of what Joanna was talking about in that clip as well, which is these women, yes, you know, we're in beautiful clothes, and we're doing all that stuff.
But we're talking about things that are important, and we're shedding light on, you know, the grey area of conversations that people should be able to have.
And I think there are cases, obviously, when you watch a TV show, you want things to work out for the characters that you're rooting for.

But we try to have the happy medium of making it aspirational for people to watch but also making sure that we do put in failures, and we do put in mess for these characters because that is what's real.
And, you know, people fail and have to pick themselves up and figure out where to go next.
And I think that our show does that really well for all of our characters.
Let me ask about the new season.
You know, Kat, Aisha, is getting comfortable in her new life.
She is a young, queer, biracial woman who's trying to figure out how much she wants to talk publicly about navigating her way through that.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""THE BOLD TYPE"")
(As Kat Edison) Cool.
(As character) Hey, I have an idea.
I want you to speak at the Scarlet Summit tomorrow.
(As Kat Edison) I'm sorry?
(As character) Think about it.
You have so much to draw from - your rise to the top of social media here, your relationship with Adena, your experiences coming out, being queer in the digital age.
You'll find a good angle.
You're going to be great.
(As Kat Edison) OK.
How are we going to see that unfold in the new season?
One of the things that I loved about the pilot script and even the show in general kind of going into it was the fact that we get to see this woman who is described as being so strong and confident.
But often, we see characters like that, and we don't feel the need to ask the question why they need to be so strong and why they need to be so confident.

And you get to see Kat be vulnerable and also kind of discovering who she is and still finding herself and finding confidence and falling in love for the first time and falling out of love for the first time.
It's been really a very special story to get to tell, and it's inspired me a lot.
And, you know, as far as I can tell from what people say in the streets, the show inspires them too.
So it's incredible.
Katie Stevens, Aisha Dee and Meghann Fahy - they are the stars of the Freeform show ""The Bold Type.
Ladies, it has been such a pleasure.

From NPR News, it's Day to day.
Think a Hummer is a gas guzzler?
Check out that RV next to you, on the highway this summer.
Today, Winnebago reports that its third-quarter profit was down 73 percent.
Marketplace's Nancy Marshall-Genzer is here now.
And I guess, Nancy, that means with gas prices so high, people just aren't out buying Winnebagos, right?
Yeah.
Winnebago dealers are having a really, really hard time.
One dealer I spoke with, though, was completely in denial, I have to say.
He said, people buying these really big, expensive RVs, are less sensitive to high gas prices, because they are - well, rich.
Another problem with that theory though, is that most of us are not rich, and that explains why sales of the biggest Winnebagos are way down.
Dealers are trying to lure customers in with all kinds of things.
They're saying, they offer excellent service, and so on.
But really - what really works, is the big price breaks they're offering.
I spoke with another RV dealer, who was more in touch with reality about how he's getting people in the door.
Allan Hoffman(ph) is vice president of Oak Lake Campground and RV Sales in Kerrick, Minnesota.
And he says they're offering big discounts, especially on those huge RVs, you know, the ones that look like buses.
I'm sure the savings can be 10 to 20 percent, on a 40,000-dollar unit, that's 4,000 dollars.
It can be healthy.
But Hoffman says, sales are still down about eight percent this year from last year.

The Jolly Flatboatmen"" is part of the exhibit, ""Navigating The West: George Caleb Bingham And The River."" It starts today at the Metropolitan Museum in New York, a show that chronicles through art the opening of the American West.
I'm Susan Stamberg, NPR News.
So what happens now now that ""Mad Men"" is over?
This is a real question that researchers have studied, and NPR's social science correspondent Shankar Vedantam is here to tell us about it.
Hi, Shankar.
Hi, Steve.
What's the research?
Well, the research tells us that after watching ""Mad Men,"" we now have to watch the stock market, Steve.
What?
And here's why.
OK.

Gabriele Lepori from Keele University in the United Kingdom was looking for ways to study the effects that fictional characters have on us and he hit on the idea of studying the effects of TV show finales in the U.S.

He has studied more than 150 popular TV show finales, starting with ""The Fugitive"" in August 1967, running through ""The Cosby Show,"" ""Seinfeld"" and ""Friends."" He's an economist and he was curious if TV finales had any effect on finance, specifically on the stock market.
What I find is that when a TV show ends, I observe a decrease in stock returns on the following trading day.
The higher the number of TV viewers for that episode, the larger the decrease in stock returns on the following day.
Wait a minute.
The stock market goes down the morning after a finale?
Why would that be?
